title: The Fed says this is a cube of $1M. They're off by half a million
text: At the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago‚Äôs Money Museum, there‚Äôs a big transparent cube on display. It‚Äôs filled with tightly packed stacks of $1\$1 bills, claiming to contain $1,000,000\$1{,}000{,}000. The plaque proudly declares: Have you ever wondered what one million dollars looks like? You don‚Äôt have to wonder anymore because you can see it right in front of you! But I don‚Äôt trust signs. I trust counting. The Big Count I first tried counting the stacks right there in the room. The cube was tall, so I had to step back to see the whole thing, squinting at the stacks, trying to follow each row. I lost track almost immediately. Also, people were starting to look at me funny. Apparently, staring intensely at a pile of cash while muttering numbers isn‚Äôt normal museum behavior. Then, I tried with a photo. I zoomed all the way in on my phone, dragging my finger across the screen, mentally tallying as I went. Still couldn‚Äôt keep count. All I wanted was a way to click on things in a photo and have the number go up. You‚Äôd think this would already exist, a browser based tool for counting things. Turns out it‚Ä¶ doesn‚Äôt. At least, not as a web app I can find on Google. There are some clunky old Windows programs, niche scientific tools, and image analysis software that assumes you‚Äôre trying to count cells under a microscope, not people, penguins, or stacks of $1 bills in a Federal Reserve cube. So I made Dot Counter. It‚Äôs stupidly simple: upload an image, click to drop a dot, and it tells you how many you‚Äôve placed. That‚Äôs it. But somehow, nothing like it existed. I originally made it to investigate this very cube, but I figured other people might need to count stuff in pictures. Now it‚Äôs yours too. Go forth. Count wisely. Count your enemies. Count your blessings. Count your stacks of cash. Because when someone tells you it‚Äôs a million dollars, you might want to double check. Final Tally Assuming each bundle contains 100100 bills*, that‚Äôs 102√ó8√ó19√ó$100=$1,550,400102 √ó 8 √ó 19 √ó \$ 100 = \$ 1{,}550{,}400*The straps on them are blue which is the standard for a stack of 100100 $1\$1 bills. Unless these are some sort of ultra-rare $64.5\$64.5 bundles. In which case, I have follow-up questions. So yeah. They‚Äôre off by 50%50\%. That‚Äôs $550,400\$550{,}400 in extra cash. Hmm ü§î Imagine the meeting. ‚ÄúHey so‚Ä¶ we‚Äôre $550,400 over budget on the million-dollar cube project.‚Äù Bad at math? If you knock 22 from each dimension (basically pealing away the outermost layer of money bundles), the math actually gets kinda close 100√ó6√ó17√ó$100=$1,020,000100 \times 6 \times 17 \times \$ 100 = \$ 1{,}020{,}000but since dollar bills are much wider than they‚Äôre tall, it wouldn‚Äôt look like a cube anymore. Inflation? Maybe the Fed is playing the long game. At the Fed‚Äôs 2%2\% inflation target, this cube will be worth $1\$1 million in today‚Äôs dollars in: log‚Å°1.02(1,550,4001,000,000)=22‚Äâyears\log_{1.02}(\frac{1{,}550{,}400}{1{,}000{,}000})=22 \thinspace\text{years}Can‚Äôt wait to come back in 2047 and say: ‚ÄúNice. Nailed it.‚Äù Technicality? Sure, it does technically contain $1,000,000\$1{,}000{,}000. And also $550,400\$550{,}400 of bonus money. Which is kind of like ordering a burger and getting three. I mean, sure, free stuff. But it‚Äôs not what you asked for. Empty inside? What if it‚Äôs hollow? You can only see the outer stacks. For all we know, the middle is just air and crumpled-up old newspaper. A money shell. A decorative cube. A fiscal illusion. The world‚Äôs most expensive pi√±ata (but don‚Äôt hit it, security is watching). And get this: just the outermost layer is already worth: [(102√ó8√ó19)‚àí(100√ó6√ó17)]√ó100=$530,400[(102 \times 8 \times 19) - (100 \times 6 \times 17)] \times 100 = \$ 530{,}400You‚Äôd only need a 3-layer-thick shell to blow past a million: [(102√ó8√ó19)‚àí(96√ó2√ó13)]√ó100=$1,300,800[(102 \times 8 \times 19) - (96 \times 2 \times 13)] \times 100 = \$ 1{,}300{,}800How would you make a million dollar cube? Turns out U.S. dollars are extremely non-cube-friendly. Each bill is 6.14‚Äâin6.14\thinspace\text{in} wide by 2.61‚Äâin2.61\thinspace\text{in} tall, a nice and even aspect ratio of: 6.142.61‚âà2.3524904...\frac{6.14}{2.61} \approx 2.3524904...Each 100-bill bundle is 0.43‚Äâin0.43\thinspace\text{in} inches thick. Best I could do 9090 bundles per stack 7√ó167 \times 16 stacks 90√ó7√ó16√ó$100=$1,008,00090 \times 7 \times 16 \times \$ 100 = \$ 1{,}008{,}000 Which gives you a lovely almost-cube: 42.97‚Äâin42.97\thinspace\text{in} (3.58‚Äâft)(3.58\thinspace\text{ft}) wide 41.76‚Äâin41.76\thinspace\text{in} (3.48‚Äâft)(3.48\thinspace\text{ft}) deep 38.70‚Äâin38.70\thinspace\text{in} (3.225‚Äâft)(3.225\thinspace\text{ft}) tall Not perfect. Not terrible. At least it‚Äôs honest, unlike that other cube. Conclusion So what‚Äôs in the cube? Maybe it‚Äôs $1\$1 million. Maybe it‚Äôs an empty box with a money shell. Most likely it‚Äôs $1.55\$1.55 million. All I know is I built a tool, did the math, and triple-checked the stacks. The sign says you don‚Äôt have to wonder. But I did anyway. And now‚Ä¶ you don‚Äôt have to either.
html:
At the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago‚Äôs Money Museum, there‚Äôs a big transparent cube on display. It‚Äôs filled with tightly packed stacks of $1\$1 bills, claiming to contain $1,000,000\$1{,}000{,}000.

The plaque proudly declares:

Have you ever wondered what one million dollars looks like? You don‚Äôt have to wonder anymore because you can see it right in front of you!

But I don‚Äôt trust signs. I trust counting.

The Big Count

I first tried counting the stacks right there in the room. The cube was tall, so I had to step back to see the whole thing, squinting at the stacks, trying to follow each row. I lost track almost immediately.

Also, people were starting to look at me funny. Apparently, staring intensely at a pile of cash while muttering numbers isn‚Äôt normal museum behavior.

Then, I tried with a photo. I zoomed all the way in on my phone, dragging my finger across the screen, mentally tallying as I went.

Still couldn‚Äôt keep count.

All I wanted was a way to click on things in a photo and have the number go up.

You‚Äôd think this would already exist, a browser based tool for counting things.

Turns out it‚Ä¶ doesn‚Äôt. At least, not as a web app I can find on Google.

There are some clunky old Windows programs, niche scientific tools, and image analysis software that assumes you‚Äôre trying to count cells under a microscope, not people, penguins, or stacks of $1 bills in a Federal Reserve cube.

So I made Dot Counter.

It‚Äôs stupidly simple: upload an image, click to drop a dot, and it tells you how many you‚Äôve placed. That‚Äôs it. But somehow, nothing like it existed.

I originally made it to investigate this very cube, but I figured other people might need to count stuff in pictures.

Now it‚Äôs yours too.

Go forth. Count wisely.

Count your enemies. Count your blessings. Count your stacks of cash.

Because when someone tells you it‚Äôs a million dollars, you might want to double check.

Final Tally

Assuming each bundle contains 100100 bills*, that‚Äôs

102√ó8√ó19√ó$100=$1,550,400102 √ó 8 √ó 19 √ó \$ 100 = \$ 1{,}550{,}400

*The straps on them are blue which is the standard for a stack of 100100 $1\$1 bills. Unless these are some sort of ultra-rare $64.5\$64.5 bundles. In which case, I have follow-up questions.

So yeah. They‚Äôre off by 50%50\%.

That‚Äôs $550,400\$550{,}400 in extra cash.

Hmm ü§î

Imagine the meeting.

‚ÄúHey so‚Ä¶ we‚Äôre $550,400 over budget on the million-dollar cube project.‚Äù

Bad at math?

If you knock 22 from each dimension (basically pealing away the outermost layer of money bundles), the math actually gets kinda close

100√ó6√ó17√ó$100=$1,020,000100 \times 6 \times 17 \times \$ 100 = \$ 1{,}020{,}000

but since dollar bills are much wider than they‚Äôre tall, it wouldn‚Äôt look like a cube anymore.

Inflation?

Maybe the Fed is playing the long game.

At the Fed‚Äôs 2%2\% inflation target, this cube will be worth $1\$1 million in today‚Äôs dollars in:

log‚Å°1.02(1,550,4001,000,000)=22‚Äâyears\log_{1.02}(\frac{1{,}550{,}400}{1{,}000{,}000})=22 \thinspace\text{years}

Can‚Äôt wait to come back in 2047 and say: ‚ÄúNice. Nailed it.‚Äù

Technicality?

Sure, it does technically contain $1,000,000\$1{,}000{,}000.

And also $550,400\$550{,}400 of bonus money.

Which is kind of like ordering a burger and getting three.

I mean, sure, free stuff. But it‚Äôs not what you asked for.

Empty inside?

What if it‚Äôs hollow?

You can only see the outer stacks. For all we know, the middle is just air and crumpled-up old newspaper.

A money shell. A decorative cube. A fiscal illusion. The world‚Äôs most expensive pi√±ata (but don‚Äôt hit it, security is watching).

And get this: just the outermost layer is already worth:

[(102√ó8√ó19)‚àí(100√ó6√ó17)]√ó100=$530,400[(102 \times 8 \times 19) - (100 \times 6 \times 17)] \times 100 = \$ 530{,}400

You‚Äôd only need a 3-layer-thick shell to blow past a million:

[(102√ó8√ó19)‚àí(96√ó2√ó13)]√ó100=$1,300,800[(102 \times 8 \times 19) - (96 \times 2 \times 13)] \times 100 = \$ 1{,}300{,}800

How would you make a million dollar cube?

Turns out U.S. dollars are extremely non-cube-friendly. Each bill is 6.14‚Äâin6.14\thinspace\text{in} wide by 2.61‚Äâin2.61\thinspace\text{in} tall, a nice and even aspect ratio of:

6.142.61‚âà2.3524904...\frac{6.14}{2.61} \approx 2.3524904...

Each 100-bill bundle is 0.43‚Äâin0.43\thinspace\text{in} inches thick.

Best I could do

  • 9090 bundles per stack
  • 7√ó167 \times 16 stacks
  • 90√ó7√ó16√ó$100=$1,008,00090 \times 7 \times 16 \times \$ 100 = \$ 1{,}008{,}000

Which gives you a lovely almost-cube:

  • 42.97‚Äâin42.97\thinspace\text{in} (3.58‚Äâft)(3.58\thinspace\text{ft}) wide
  • 41.76‚Äâin41.76\thinspace\text{in} (3.48‚Äâft)(3.48\thinspace\text{ft}) deep
  • 38.70‚Äâin38.70\thinspace\text{in} (3.225‚Äâft)(3.225\thinspace\text{ft}) tall

Not perfect. Not terrible. At least it‚Äôs honest, unlike that other cube.

Conclusion

So what‚Äôs in the cube?

Maybe it‚Äôs $1\$1 million.

Maybe it‚Äôs an empty box with a money shell.

Most likely it‚Äôs $1.55\$1.55 million.

All I know is I built a tool, did the math, and triple-checked the stacks.

The sign says you don‚Äôt have to wonder. But I did anyway.

And now‚Ä¶ you don‚Äôt have to either.
